title: Why Pre-Workout Makes You Itchy (And How to Stop It)

steps.title: Beta-alanine produces a byproduct that causes tingling and itchiness.
steps.content: Beta-alanine produces a byproduct that causes tingling and itchiness. Beta-alanine is the beta amino-acid inside of pre-workout that delays muscle fatigue and loss of power. However, beta-alanine can also cause an effect called paresthesia, which isn’t harmful, but does cause tingling and itching. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Researchers aren’t 100% certain why beta-alanine does this inside the body, but it’s common enough that more studies are being done on it.

steps.title: Split your dosage up into several smaller doses.
steps.content: Split your dosage up into several smaller doses. Many people find that instead of taking an entire dose at once, breaking up their pre-workout into 2 or 3 doses helps prevent the itching. Try taking smaller amounts of pre-workout throughout the day to stop that tingly feeling. [2] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Pre-workout typically lasts in your system for about 4 hours. Try starting your first dose about 4 hours before you plan to work out.

steps.title: Try a sustained-release beta-alanine pre-workout.
steps.content: Try a sustained-release beta-alanine pre-workout. Since beta-alanine is the ingredient that causes the itching, researchers have found that a sustained-release formula helps circumvent uncomfortable side effects. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Look for a pre-workout that says “sustained-release” on the packaging to try out this new version. Try Vintage Blast for a sustained-release pre-workout. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Take a pre-workout without beta-alanine.
steps.content: Take a pre-workout without beta-alanine. Beta-alanine is the ingredient that causes the pre-workout itch. While beta-alanine is a common ingredient in pre-workouts, you can find pre-workout brands without beta-alanine. These formulas may be better for you if you’re particularly sensitive to the side effects of beta-alanine. Look for brands like Gorilla Mode , 4 Gauge , or Pre-Lab Pro . [5] X Research source

steps.title: Itchiness usually lasts between 15 minutes and 1 hour.
steps.content: Itchiness usually lasts between 15 minutes and 1 hour. The itchy, tingly feeling is different for everyone: for some people, it lasts for 15 minutes, and for others, it keeps itching and tingling for over 60 minutes. Some people even feel no itchiness at all. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: The recommended dose of beta-alanine is 4 to 6 grams per day.
steps.content: The recommended dose of beta-alanine is 4 to 6 grams per day. However, your pre-workout may be formulated differently, so always check the instructions on the bottle. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Taking more than the recommended amount of beta-alanine could increase uncomfortable side effects, so it’s best to follow the directions closely.

steps.title: Yes, beta-alanine has been well-researched and is safe to use.
steps.content: Yes, beta-alanine has been well-researched and is safe to use. Beta-alanine is a naturally-occurring amino acid that’s also found in meat, poultry, and fish. Studies show no long-term side effects after using beta-alanine, and itchiness and tingling have been the only major side effects reported. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Only about 30% of pre-workout users experience itching and tingling.
